title: Xbox will weed out bullying and rude messages between online gamers with new message filters
text:
Even in the pantheon of abusive internet communities, online gaming is notorious for being an unpleasant sphere.

That's why Microsoft has started to tamp down on abuse that originates on its Xbox Live platform via a new set of message filters they hope will root out toxic interactions.

'At Xbox, we are investing in building a positive gaming community,' the company wrote in a blog post on Monday.

'We believe that gaming should be inclusive and welcoming for everyone, which means creating experiences and communities that invite everyone to play safely and responsibly.'

Xbox is the latest major platform to begin testing a filter designed to weed out messages that contain mature language in an effort to tamp down on abuse

According to the company, its new message filters will affect several aspects of the Xbox Live platform, including content that appears in profiles, messages, clubs, and activity feeds and will come in varying degrees of strenuousness.

Polygon reports that while Microsoft hasn't released specifics of how each degree of filter will work precisely, there are some general guidelines.

'Friendly,' the most restrictive filter setting, will automatically get rid of nearly all swear words and content that parents may find objectionable for children; 'Medium' will filter out most offensive language aside from select language; Mature is a bare-bones filter while 'unfiltered' provides no content restrictions.

Microsoft says that its filters are also designed to pick up words that specifically qualify as bullying.

Twitter is among the platforms fighting to make people safe from a deluge of abuse that has affected many of its users

If a message is blocked, the end-user receives a warning instead of the actual underlying content that reads 'potentially offensive message hidden.'

A users logged into Xbox Live as an adult can then choose to view that message while anyone using the platform as a minor is unable to view the original note.

The company has yet to provide a specific release date for when it plans to roll out the features but will be available for Xbox Insiders - a tier or users who agree to test betas and provide feedback to the company - today.

Microsoft will join a growing wave of major platforms in working to make their communities safer for users that includes major social media giants like Facebook and Twitter.

Notably, Twitter has begun to test out similar message filters in the last several months that are designed to interdict abuse before it reaches a victim.
description: Message filters will affect several aspects of the Xbox Live platform, including content that appears in profiles, messages, clubs, and activity feeds. It will come in varying degrees as well.
